title: 103_hr3650
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Dietary Supplement Access and Claims Moratorium Act of 1993". The Congress finds that many consumers use dietary supplements and there is public concern about FDA regulations. Congress will extend the moratorium on FDA actions regarding health claims on dietary supplements. TITLE I--ACCESS TO DIETARY SUPPLEMENTS

SEC. 101. REFERENCE.

Amendments or repeals in this title refer to sections of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act.

SEC. 102. ACCESS TO DIETARY SUPPLEMENTS. The FDA may not require prescriptions for dietary supplements marketed before November 15, 1993, and may not require premarket approval for dietary ingredients in supplements. The FDA does not require prescriptions for dietary supplements marketed before November 15, 1993. Amendments to sections 201 and 402 of the U.S. Code address the classification of dietary supplements and the burden of proof on the FDA regarding injurious health effects. The term 'dietary ingredient' includes vitamins, minerals, herbs, amino acids, and other ingredients in products marketed as dietary supplements in the US before November 15, 1993. A 'dietary supplement' is a product containing one or more dietary ingredients marketed to supplement the diet, not as conventional food. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will issue a regulation within 180 days after the enactment of the Act to identify dietary ingredients marketed before November 15, 1993, which are not represented as conventional food or as a sole item of a meal, and do not include any ingredient other than a vitamin or mineral approved as a drug. TITLE II--MORATORIUM ON DIETARY SUPPLEMENT CLAIMS

SEC. 201. REFERENCE.

    Amendments or repeals in this title refer to sections of the Prescription Drug User Fee Act of 1992.

SEC. 202. PROHIBITION OF IMPLEMENTATION.

    Amends Section 202(a)(1) to extend the deadline to June 30, 1994, and includes "amino acids" after "herbs."

SEC. 203. ISSUANCE OF REGULATIONS.

    Amends regulations to extend the deadline to June 30, 1994, and includes "amino acids" after "herbs."

SEC. 204. STATE ENFORCEMENT. SEC. 204. STATE ENFORCEMENT.

The amendment made by section 202(a)(3) is amended to dietary supplements of vitamins, minerals, herbs, amino acids, or other similar nutritional substances on June 30, 1994.

SEC. 205. CLAIM APPROVAL.

Section 202(b) is amended by changing the deadline to June 30, 1994, and adding "amino acids," after "herbs,".
